Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2007 05:31PM - edited Dec 29, 2007 05:32PM by Roja1955 I had to have my port removed after one month - I was having a reaction to the stitches (so I kept telling them), but went through the whole antibiotics treatment because they said it was infected - (cultured negative).  I had the second port inserted by a surgeon (the first was by a radiologist), and requested she place it under my clavicle (the first one was literally over the clavicle and obvious and uncomfortable.  I also requested that she use steri-strips, but she suggested glue, which worked great.  I barely notice my new port.  Discomfort for a day or two, but you'll be able to go about your business...  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Port Question AO44 Areyousure

Posts.Content: Roja1955 wrote: I went for my 2nd opinion @ UNC Chapel Hill last week.  In one week's time, I have had a breast bx on my right breast, MRI of my liver and Ct on my kidney.  Today the results are:  I have a "new" breast cancer in my right breast (original was in my left), I have 2 lesions on my liver, and my kidney is fine, except there an adnexal mass that is putting pressure on it and causing a hydronephrosis  (plan for possible stent - pending urology appt.)  Shock with a second breast cancer, and they immediately are testing me for the BRACA I/II gene.  I want to have the breast removed and if possible a hysterectomy, since I understand I am not high risk for ovarian cancer.  Doc wants to get me stable first - Plan - start chemo (Navelbine) - anyone out there that is taking this (3 weeks on - one week off)...  I'm scared and shocked that this happened during my chemo break and I was on the horrific AI's - 4 months total....  I feel like I'm in this pit and it just keeps getting deeper.  Thanks for listening ladies and God Bless....  Dx 9/11/2007, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/9 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 12:25AM Roja1955 wrote: Bonnieva:  Maybe if you switch to weekly Abaxane it my help with side effects - they are more tolerable.  I have been on Taxol and Avastin weekly for 5+ months, and having minimal side effects.  My once said he would change meds if I started to have the neuropathy in hands/feet.  Talk with your onc and see if changing dosage/time will work better.  I have read that Avastin works better with Abraxane.  Does he do the combo?  Hang in there.  RobinWendy:  I think you and I have been doing the same treatments, except backwards...  When dx with mets in Sept. I was started on Taxol and avastin.  I am now working into my six month, and was told by one onc to stay on until progression or cannot tolerate it.  The second onc recommends a chemo break at six months.  He will continue Avastin and add an AI.  I will have a pet scan before the change in meds, and I do want to take a break.  I like the way they presented to you to stay on until you cannot tolerate or NED.  Hope I'm not ditching this too soon.  Decisions, decisions.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 10:51PM Roja1955 wrote: I have a adnexal mass (in my pelvis-ovary), which was dx. after a routine PET showing I had an enlarged kidney.  This mass is applying pressure on my kidney.  I want it out, and also requesting a hysterectomy.  I just started chemo - Navelbine and my onc says depending on the surgery date I would only be off the chemo for a week before and after.  Now, saying all that, I still haven't seen the gyn onc, but I am insisting on the hysterectomy.  I'm told this can be done laprascopic, which is much less invasive.  In the meantime, I am having a stent put in my kidney until surgery (late October time frame).  It does seem like a long time for a chemo break - anything non-chemo in the meantime because you risk progression.  Yes, chemo could very well zap that mets to your ovary.   I've read something about removing the tumor load which helps for extended survival???  Ugh - decisions decisions.....

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2008 02:55AM Roja1955 wrote: I have pleural effusion mets, and my symptoms intially was a cough.  Dr. did CT scan and  unknown to me had a collapsed lung.  I had a thorocentesis and tap off 1.5 liters of fluid.  Much improvement, and also had a VAT procedure done, where they biopsied my pleural and cause some adhesions to my lining, so fluid would not continue to build (there's a talc procedure as well).  I was told the fluid could come back since my lung has not fully expanded, so they can drain as needed or put in a permament stent. Fluid continues to be minimal and no further taps.  Have they offered the pleurodosis procedure to her?  Wish her well and the new drugs kick butt.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 09:45PM Roja1955 wrote: I never heard of Horner's syndrome, but I hope Ravdeb's comments have set you in the right direction.  If you are postmenopausal, maybe they should put you on Arimidex.  I was on Tamoxifen  and it failed me, (I was on it for 4 years before dx with  lung mets), and my onc kept offering me the Arimidex, as it works better for postmenopausal women, but I had the option since I have RA, and Arimidex can cause joint pain, so I decided to say on the tamoxifen.  Tamoxifen works primarily on the ovaries (which are not working now anyway).  Will always wonder if I took the Arimidex, maybe I wouldn't be here...  Congratulations on 10 years stability!

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 10:02AM Roja1955 wrote: I came to this site when I had to have a second port (the first one I had to have remove because of infection-which is rare) inserted and got so much suggestions from everyone, which I think made the difference in how it all turned out.  Make sure they place it under your clavicle; mark the area where your bra usually lays, so they can try and place it off that area; ask the surgeon how experienced at placing; if you have reactions to tape, as for them to "glue" it.  My experience in discomfort was minimal during and after, and I barely know its there.  I do love my port!

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 10:56PM Roja1955 wrote: I always wonder if I'm going the right route with my treatments...  I live in a county bumkin area, and the big cancer center closet to me is 3+ hours.  I see these wonderful commercials about cancer centers that treat the whole person, yada, yada...  Yet, I do trust my  local onc and hope I am getting the best care possible.  Then I wonder should I seek out these Anderson/Dana places??  Bottom line is I'm trying to stay on top of the lastest and greatest - questioning my onc about other treatments, etc.  But if I had these places closer and available to me - I would do it.  What have we got to lose?  Only something more to gain.  Go for it!
Posts.Title: What About Dana Farber? Kasey Kasey

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 09:43AM Roja1955 wrote: I had complications after one month port insertion by a Radiologist. It never felt right, got infected and had to have it removed.  I came to this site for advice for the next go around, and everyone gave such great advice in regard to placing under clavicle, marking area where bra normally sits, etc.  I think my main problem with my first port was I was allergic to the stiches.  So for the second one, I got a surgeon and I also told her of my concern with stitches.  So she said she would use glue, which worked wonders...  I love this new port and don't even know its there!

Posts.Content: Roja1955 wrote: I have had progression with my last CT scan (chest area and liver).  My county bumkin onc. just says we change to another hormonal - Faslodex.  I question the chest area and liver lesion (mention RFA) and he just says we treat it systemically.  I also told him of a lump I feel in my right breast - he says it's probably from the chest wall....  Went to get a second opion (actually my first onc when I started this ride 5 years ago - she is a breast ca onc  @ Chapel Hill, NC).  I brought all my records/PET results.  I told her my concerns and when she felt my breast lump, she immediately set me down for a mamo and u/s.  Yep - there's a mass there and tomorrow I go for a fine needle biopsy.  I told her of my concern of this liver lesion - and she concurred and I also have a MRI of liver tomorrow as well.  Well, I'm changing back to her as I feel she is much more assertive and hopefully we'll get some concrete answers...  I'm praying this "mass" is just in my breast and not chest area.  I'm praying the liver lesion is benign...  Can breast cancer come back to the breast after mets??  And would they do a mastectomy if it is there, or because I'm now a metster, they don't go there?  Can't help but feel my country onc is not real proactive and I get the impression that he does not have hope for me....  Thanks for listening and God Bless you all.  Dx 9/11/2007, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/9 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
